children.subject: I would be surprised if a graduate school penalized you in any way with your decision to PNP a college requirement like AC--usually they only take your overall GPA as listed on your transcript or only consider your CS major requirements. Some programs with extra requirements like pre-med might consider GPA for only those requirements in addition to your overall GPA. Plus, your grad application wouldn't be reviewed by a computer, real understanding people will be looking at your grades, but probably more importantly your LoRs and research/teaching/work experiences. Of course, you can review the application guidelines set by the schools in which you're interested, but you should probably act in the interests of maximizing your CS grades and getting other relevant experiences; and if that means PNP'ing your AC course (bc it's jeopardizing your other grades/time for research/teaching/stress levels), you should do that.

In some cases, there is also a process for requesting (from the instructor of the course, or the department--I'm not exactly sure which) the letter grade which you would have gotten had you not PNP'd, though its not likely you will need to do this. The classes you should be more concerned about PNP'ing are CS courses and other relevant technical courses.
Thank you for your very thorough answers!

I know it makes no impact on UC Berkeley's calculation of GPA but is it possible graduate schools will calculate GPA differently? I have anecdotally heard that graduate schools treat P's as C's for example.

history.content: As long as you're not taking tons of classes P/NP, I don't think anyone looking at your transcript for grad school is going to care. I have read applications for the MEng program, and I was never paying much attention to what someone's grade in their AC class was (unless they got a D or an F...then I might notice).

children.subject: Probably don't, if you can help it. It really may depend on the particular class, since recruiters probably won't be able to tell what classes you used for major and which ones you didn't, they'll just see you PNP'd a CS course. If the course is relevant to your interests or future job, you shouldn't do it. If not, it's still probably best not to, as any CS class may end up being useful in some way. But if your other classes are more important to you and you think their grades will actually improve substantially from PNP'ing the one, perhaps do it (if you are trying to get research in those areas, or go to grad. school, an A in those might help you a lot). But for job recruiting, I am more hesitant to say you should since your GPA isn't really that important, so to a recruiter it won't really matter what you do; but if you entertain the idea of grade-dependent positions (research/teaching/grad school) and aren't sure in which specific area, probably don't.

Also, take into account future semesters if you plan to take similar workloads--you may want to use that class for your major reqs. and save the PNP for later if you foresee ever having an even more difficult semester in the future.
Is it common for recruiters to ask for transcripts before an offer is extended and how big of a role does it play? I only know of Google who asks.
I'm taking three tech courses. What will be the consequence if I PNP one of them (don't need it to count as major requirement, but afraid that PNP a tech will hurt recruiting?)
No it's quite common to P/NP AC class

history.content: I was considering Pass/No Passing my American Cultures requirement course this semester. However, I also would like to keep my options open for pursuing graduate school in computer science. Are there any negative consequences for P/NPing a nontechnical class in terms of graduate school admissions? Do they look upon such a P/NP in a negative light? Does it affect how they or UC Berkeley calculate your GPA?
history.subject: P/NP Consequences
